comments.raw_text:
When selecting to not treat messages from users who are in the personal addressbook as junk/spam, emails marked by spam-assassin are nevertheless handled as spam if one decides to trust spam-assassin in the corresponding checkbox.

Setting/steps to reproduce:

Mail&Newsgroup Account-Settings => Account => Junk settings:
[x] Enable adaptive junk mail controls for this account 
Do not mark mail as junk if the sender is in:
[x] Personal Address Book

[x] Trust junk mail headers set by: [SpamAssassin]

Put the sender-address into your Personal Address-Book.
Wait for an email which is being classified as spam by spam-assassin. (the user reporting this issue was experiencing this for EVERY email of an AOL-user from whom he was receiving emails)

Expected result: Sender is trusted due to personal Addressbook and settings above and email not treated as junk.

Actual result: Email is being treated as Junk.


Disabling the Spam-Assassin checkbox instantly resolves the problem, so this is not an issue of the internal spam-detection but with the treatment of marked emails. (Therefore might also affect the SpamPal setting instead of SpamAssassin)

User testet with Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; de; rv:1.9.1.19)
Gecko/20110420 Mnenhy/0.8.3 SeaMonkey/2.0.14

I'm not the position to reproduce this bug due to the lack of a corresponding Email-Account known to have Spam-Assassin and a "verified junk sender" (in terms of spam assassin's classification), just reporting this issue due to the language barrier for the original user experiencing this problem.

Perhaps the panel arrangement needs to be rethought?

comments.raw_text:
This seems to me to be a dupe of bug 678960.

I think the panel arrangement is correct and shows the current state of the feature. Whitelist by AB is a subfeature of "adaptive junk mail controls" (inside TB) and does not relate to spamassasin (or any other server filter).

If somebody implements the feature, the panel needs to be updated too.
